text: What's up outliers? Today we're going to talk about how to read an options chain. Believe it or not, there is a ton of really useful information baked into an options chain that most traders kind of gloss over because they don't know what to look for. So we're going to do a quick recap of what the chain is, how to read it from a basic perspective. And then I'm going to give you a look inside a more advanced way to pull information to make better informed trades. So what is an options chain? And that's this thing right here. It's essentially where all of the listed options for a security exist. And it shows you all of your different choices with respect to options. Now we're going to be looking at a live options chain. Well, the on the platform itself versus this screenshot. I just wanted to give you something. If you want to grab a screenshot or something as we go through this so that you kind of have an idea of like the key metrics that we're going to work through. So let's get into the weeds. So first I have Palantir up here just as an example. And the first thing I want you to notice are all of these different aspirations. These are also known as series as terms, but every option's chain is going to have different expiration cycles. And you'll notice that there are some that are broken out into

And you'll notice that there are some that are broken out into these yellow text labeled weekly. And then the rest are kind of like this gray text. These are normal explorations, the gray text. And they represent the third Friday of the month, standard options expiration. And then there's weeklies. And if you look at something like SPX, there's even daily options. The main note is that in general, most of the liquidity is going to be in the standard options expiration. And that's simply because that's where larger institutions and entities gather together because they know that the other one's going to be there. It's kind of like going to play basketball and knowing which court to go to because that's where the people are out of the version of that. Then you'll notice that for every single one of these explorations, there's a different implied volatility. Every expiration has its own implied volatility. The first thing you'll see here is bid as spread. And the bid ask shows us first the bid. That is the most somebody is willing to buy something for it. That's their bid. And then the ask is the cheapest somebody is willing to sell something for it. So essentially if you were going and you were like, I want to buy an option, you have to go towards the ask. And if I want to sell an option, you go towards the bid. Now one of the cool things is you'll notice that there's a gap in between these and we can try to transact towards the middle of this gap. So if we click into this and hit buy, you'll notice how there's this little bar down here that shows the mid price and then the natural, which is whatever you would get hit at the bid or the offer respectively. So you can actually try to play it from the mid. text: in on this row that's now highlighted in blue for you, you'll see the last price is 360. That's the last price this option traded at. Then you'll notice this next is Delta, which measures the rate of change of premium per one point move in the underlying. That means if Palantir goes up by 1, the premium of your option, Seteris, Parabis, everything else remaining the same would move up 41 cents. Then you have your gamma, which is your rate of change of Delta per one point move in the underlying. So that means that if Palantir did go up by a dollar, you would make your 41 cents from your Delta, but then your Delta would also grow by three pennies from 41 to 43. Next up, you have Theta. You'll notice that Theta is negative. This is the rate of change of premium per one day passing. And as we know, options decay. So that means from today to tomorrow, this option here will lose 13 cents. Next up, we have Vega. This represents the premium rate of change per one percent change in implied volatility. So if the implied volatility in Palantir goes up by 1, this option here would go up by 8 cents. So there's a lot we can use the Greeks for. And specifically, it's to help us fine tune our positions. I have an entire video that walks through that in depth. We'll throw a link to that in the notes

Volume, which is this one represents the number of this specific option that traded today. So for this 90 call, there is 56, 77 contracts traded today. We don't know if those are opening contracts for closing contracts. We just know that they traded today. Then over here, this 88, 82, that represents open interest. These are contracts that are currently open. This metric can go up or down. New contracts can be open so it can go up from 88, 82 or it can go down because people can close contracts. This updates overnight and it's not updated throughout the day. So this means this 88, 82 will stay like that all day. And then at the end of the day, the volume that occurred today will be integrated into the open interest, whether that volume is opening trades, then this number would go up open interest. A lot of people will use delta as an approximation for a probability, which is generally okay. I have an entire video dissecting acts. It's not fully accurate. You can actually see it's not accurate right here, because this column here shows us the probability of being in the money at expiration. And then this column here shows us the probability of a touch sometime before expiration. And you can see that the probability of being in the money at expiration is 34.54. But this shows you 41. So you see that's actually pretty big gap. So delta is somewhat useful for that, but it's not perfect. Now the last two columns I'm going to show you are currently the size. This is an assessment of liquidity. Notice how there's only two at the bid at 350. And then there's 183 at the offer at 385. What does this tell us? Well, it tells us that there is a really small offering to essentially take these at the 350. There's only two contracts that are offered at that price. So for some reason, people really aren't wanting to trade at the bid. So they are sizing it down a lot. But you can see for the ask side of the equation, it's kind of different. There's 183 offered at this 385. So we're more open to trade at this.
